bioghist.p: Alan C. Nixon (1909-2002) was a research chemist with Shell Development and served as president of the American Chemical Society (ACS). In 1968, he founded Project SEED, a program that offered economically disadvantaged students the opportunity to work in chemistry settings. He was well known to readers of the Vortex, the publication of the California section of the ACS, for which he wrote a column, "Nick Nacks." Following retirement, he founded Calsec Consultants, a Berkeley company made up of about 70 retired chemists, chemical engineers, and other scientists that provided consulting services to the public.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of copies of articles written by Nixon. His column "Employment" was published in the Vortex from 1965 to 1971. In 1971, the subjects of Nixon's Vortex articles became more general, and they were published under the title "Nick Nacks." There is some overlap between the two articles in 1971. Many editions of "Nick Nacks" from 1971 to 1996 are present in this collection in a pre-print format. Some of the pre-printed articles never appeared in the Vortex. Also included in this collection is a bound set of humorous letters exchanged among a group of friends and Nixon's curriculum vitae.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
